evidence: Alloy Nb0.25 shows yield strength of 748 MPa, fracture strength of 843 MPa and ductility of 14.2%. With the decrease of Nb content (i.e., Nb0.2), the fracture strength and plasticity appreciably increase to 983 MPa and 31.8%, respectively. Nevertheless, the yield strength decreases to 607 MPa.
The as-cast Nb0.2 alloy assumes a dual-phase structure of HCP and BCC, which is consistent with the EBSD and XRD results.
Nb0.25 exhibits relatively ductile deformation behavior with a fracture strain of 14.2%
Compared with HfTa0.5TiZr, the fracture strength (983 MPa) and plasticity (31.8%) of Nb0.2 are further increased due to the addition of Nb.

As shown in Fig.  1b , the work hardening rate in the latter part of stage III shows a slow decline behavior until zero, rendering the fracture strength and plasticity to 1003 MPa and 25.8%, respectively.
Hence, a high yield strength (≈1206 MPa) and fracture strength (≈1315 MPa) but very limited plasticity (≈4.1%) were obtained, as shown in Fig.  1a .

This work investigated effects of the BCC-stabilizer Nb on the phase constitution, phase stability, work hardening and mechanical properties of the HfNbxTa0.2TiZr HEAs. The results revealed that the proportion and stability of prior BCC and phase transformation ratio of BCC during deformation are strongly dependent on the amount of Nb. Decreasing the Nb content reduces the BCC phase stability and promotes the martensitic transformation from BCC to HCP upon loading. Moreover, additional mechanical twinning in the product HCP phase was also activated due probably to the lower SFE resulted from the Nb addition, giving rise to an enhanced sustained strain hardening rate and thus a superior combination of strength (983 MPa) and uniform ductility (>26%), which surmounts the level of most BCC refractory HEAs reported previously.
